title: Chapter 7 in california. 703 exemptions. Pending worker's comp case. What exemptions are available to protect my case?
question: I am not even sure whether I will win or not, but want to know if this is something exemptable in a CA bankruptcy chapter 7
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Bankruptcy exemptions,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Work-related personal injuries,Employment,Employment law and finances,Workers' compensation,Unemployment compensation
answers:
Both the 703 and 704 series have exemptions for these kinds of awards. However, there is a wrinkle. Right now you don't know what this is worth as the case has not yet been completed. If you file for bankruptcy, it becomes part of the bankruptcy estate, and is subject to control by the BK trustee.

Make sure you list the pending case in the BK, give it an estimated value, and apply the exemptions to that value so it is 100% exempt. You should be in good shape.

It depends on what any such worker's comp. payment would be for. Are you alleging disability? Illness? or what. Under the 703 series, your exemption claim could possibly fit under 703.140(b)(10)(C) "disability, illness, or unemployment benefit." However, if you do not have to use the 703 exemptions (i.e. it is not crucial that you have the 703 "wildcard" available), then you could use the 704 series instead, in which case your worker's comp. claim and any benefits received, would more clearly be exempt under 704.160.

If the INSURER goes bankrupt, the claim is covered by the California Insurance Guarantee Association, CIGA for short... if the employer is bankrupt, you just face 'discharge' of a judgement for a Serious & Willful Misconduct of The Employer or the LC132a award, presuming there was insurance paid up at the moment of the industrial injury. If there was no insurance and the employer gets the work injury debt discharged, CIGA takes over and your covered.

Workers Compensation Claims or a portion of them may be exempt in California depending upon what exemptions you chose and what other assets you may have to protect. You should speak to a bankruptcy attorney to determine the risks and benefits of filing a bankruptcy. Most bankruptcy attorneys will not charge for an initial consultation. They will ask for information about your assets, income, expenses and debts to determine if filing makes sense and what can be exempted.

Your workers compensation claim should not be. They hopefully have insurance and your claim will be unaffected by the filing. However if they are uninsured, it is still usually not effected, but your attorney may have some hoops to jump through. If you have a claim for Labor Code 132a or Serious and Willful misconduct, these however may be impacted by the filing.
